awd_titl_txt: Influence of Solute Incorporation Mechanisms on the Properties of Highly Mismatched Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Highly mismatched alloys are materials that contain chemical elements with very different atomic sizes and different ability to attract nearby electrons. When a few atoms with larger or smaller sizes are added to an alloy, its electrical and optical properties often change dramatically. The goal of this research is to examine the impact of the atoms' local surroundings on the electronic and optical properties of alloy films and multi-layer structures, with an eye towards engineering structures for temperature-insensitive lasers, high-selectivity spin valves, and high efficiency photovoltaics. The project provides training to graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, engaging them in collaborations with investigators from several universities and laboratories throughout the world. The new knowledge acquired is broadly disseminated through publications and presentations, and graduate and undergraduate curriculum development. Outreach activities emphasize the mentoring of women and underrepresented minorities. 

Technical Description: The project is focused on fundamental understanding of solute incorporation mechanisms and their influence on the electronic states, transport, and optoelectronic properties of highly mismatched alloys. The primary goal of the project is to develop a predictive framework for the influence of substitutional N and Bi atoms, as well as N-As, N-N, or N-Bi pairs, on the properties of both random and ordered GaAs(BiN) alloy films and heterostructures. The GaAs(BiN) alloys are prepared on a variety of substrates using plasma-assisted molecular-beam epitaxy, followed by post-epitaxy rapid-thermal annealing sequences. The interplay between surface reconstruction, surface stress and local electronic states is monitored in real-time using in-situ reflection high-energy electron diffraction, multi-beam optical stress sensing and scanning tunneling microscopy/spectroscopy. The alloy stoichiometry and local atomic environments are examined using atom-probe tomography and novel channeling ion beam analyses. To determine the correlations between solute incorporation mechanisms and electronic states, the experimental transport and spectroscopic data is compared with both atomistic and density-functional theory computations. In addition to determining the composition dependence of band offsets of quaternary alloys with respect to GaAs, signatures for nested versus staggered band offsets are examined using scanning tunneling spectroscopy and time-resolved photoluminescence. The project at the University of Michigan involves collaborations with scientists at national laboratories and international universities, providing broad range of opportunities for the participating students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

Highly mismatched alloys (HMAs) consist of highly immiscible solute atoms in a solvent. Due to resonant interactions between the conduction and/or valence band of the solvent and solute energy levels, HMAs may provide an “intermediate band” for solar cells based upon multi-photon excitation. In addition, resonant levels in HMAs have been proposed for high efficiency thermoelectrics based upon tuning the electron density of states. Finally, the resonant interactions between solute energy levels and the valence band are predicted to enhance spin-orbit splitting, enabling temperature-insensitive lasing. Typically, HMAs are described by a 2-level model, which considers interactions between conduction band (CB) or valence band (VB) edge states and localized solute states. Single local environment models predict energy band gap trends for III-As (Bi, N, P, Sb) and Zn-Te (S, Se, O); however, they do not predict extraordinary physical phenomena, such as persistent photoconductivity and non-monotonic composition-dependences of the effective mass and gyromagnetic factor. For GaAsBi, a non-monotonic composition-dependence of spin-orbit splitting has been reported, and VB splitting is predicted to depend strongly on the local Bi solute atom arrangement. In addition, atomic ordering has been reported in GaAsBi and other dilute HMAs. Since CuPt ordering induces zone-folding which lowers the CB edge, splits the VB states, and lowers the split-off band, it is anticipated that further modifications to the 2-level model are needed to provide a complete description of electronic states in HMAs. Building upon our expertise in identifying local atomic environments for N in GaAs(Bi), we examined the impact of those environments on electronic and optical properties of alloy films and heterostructures, with an eye towards engineering structures for optoelectronics, photovoltaics, and electronics. During this project, we made several important contributions to understanding solute incorporation and correlating incorporation mechanisms with properties of a wide range of HMAs.

  • Discovered tetrahedral interstitial incorporation into GaAsN alloys
  • First local-electrode atom-probe tomography (LEAP) study of GaAsNBi alloys, revealing minimal Bi clustering and the role of excess arsenic on transport properties
  • Demonstrated first measurement of conduction band offsets and confined states at GaAs/GaAsNBi/GaAs heterointerfaces
  • Discovered that high-energy electron irradiation generates point defects whose formation and migration enhance the recovery of substitutional N in GaAsNBi
  • Determined critical band parameters for GaAsNBi heterostructure simulations
  • Identified the role of incorporating surfactants on chemical ordering in GaAsN:Bi
  • Discovered a new magic ratio for lattice-matching of GaAsNBi alloys to GaAs
  • Developed a new map of the composition-bandgap relationship for GaAsNBi alloys
  • Identified the Bi impurity state in GaAsNBi
  • Determined the influence of alloy phase separation on GaAsN effective band gaps 
  • Achieved first high-resolution angle-resolved photoemission spectra from  GaAsBi:Si
  • Revealed mechanisms for co-incorporation of Sn and C in GeSnC alloys
  • Demonstrated signatures for rocksalt inclusion formation in AlScN alloys
  • Origins of photoluminescence from sub-monolayer epitaxial quantum dots
  • Dopant versus Free Carrier Concentrations in InAs/GaAs Quantum Dots

Broader Impact

During the 5.5 years of this grant, our investigations resulted in 19 publications, including 14 published, 2 pending, and 3 in preparation; 36 student conference presentations;and 24 invited talks by the PI. Furthermore, 8 graduate and 22 undergraduate (UG) students have participated in this program. The project is inclusive of underrepresented groups as 10 undergraduates and 3 graduate students are women, 3 graduate students are African-American, and 1 graduate student is Mexican American.

Note that although the project has provided research training to 8 different graduate students, the funding from this grant supported only 1 of them during any given semester. In addition, AGEP and INTERN supplements partially supported 3 graduate students. One graduate student received her research M.S. degree and returned to Taiwan. UGs participated in the research through a variety of programs, including the NSF-supported REU programs at UM physics, and the Lurie Nanofabrication Facility, an Intel-supported undergraduate research program hosted at UM, and other summer undergraduate research awards from UM (physics, UMEI-UROP, and SURE).

All students learned about novel semiconducting alloys and their importance for electronic and optoelectronic device applications. In addition, the students learned various technical skills including ultra-high vacuum techniques, AutoCad design, and Mathematica programming. Most graduate students present papers at national conferences before the end of their first year of graduate school. The graduate students are encouraged to apply for both conference travel and research travel funds through the Rackham graduate school. To accommodate new students, we utilize a mentoring system to assist them in coming up to speed. In addition to mentoring of undergraduates and high school students by graduate students, senior graduate students serve as mentors for new graduate students. Both undergraduate and graduate students attend weekly group meetings, which often consist of a presentation from one or more students. More than 50% of the undergraduate students who participated in this project have enrolled in top-ranked graduate schools following their graduation. Two undergraduates received NSF Graduate Research Fellowships.
